Royal Asiatic Society
North China Branch

Exhibition of Chinese Paintings
From the Collection of
Herr Rudolf Mahnfeldt

June 7-9, 1912
In the Building of the Society
5 Museum Road
Shanghai
Notes on the Periods of Chinese Painting

Tang Dynasty 600-900

Very few genuine specimens are left and it is very difficult to get a clear impression of what the great masters of the Tang Dynasty achieved. The prominent masters are Wu-tao-tzu, the greatest of Chinese painters; Li-ssu-hsin, the founder of the northern school of landscape painters; and Wang-wei, the painter of romantic landscapes of the southern school.

Five Dynasties 900-960

Sung Dynasty 960-1280

This, the classical period of Chinese painting, is characterized by grandeur of conception, simplicity of style and power of interpreting the soul of nature. The most famous names are Li-ying-ch'iu, landscapes full of soul; Tung-yuan, rainy landscapes; Li-lung-mien, religious subjects; Su-tung-po, bamboo sketches in black and white; Mi-fei, landscapes; Emperor Sung-hui-tsung, birds, especially falcons; Chao-po-kü, human figures and landscapes; Mu-chi, tigers; Ma-yuan and Hsia-kuei, landscapes.

Yuan Dynasty 1280-1368

This period has not the grandeur of conception of the Sung. Its paintings are of a more delicate and idyllic style. The most noted artists are Chao-tzu-ting, horses and landscapes; Chien-hsian, human figures, flowers and birds; Huang-kung-wang, Kao-ko-kung and Waug-meng, landscapes.

Ming Dynasty 1368-1644

This is the romantic period. The composition is in general not centralized. There is growing individuality of style. The objects depicted are full of spirit and life. Amongst more than twelve hundred artists there are T'ang-yin, the most famous of all Ming painters; Ch'i-ting-ying, the distinguished copyist; Shên-chou, landscapes; Wên-cheng-ming, the great colourist, in landscapes; Lü-ki, famous for flowers and birds; Tung-ch'i-ch'ang, foremost in landscapes; Lu-pao-shan, flowers and birds and landscapes; and Ting-yün-p'êng, landscapes, figures and portraits.
Ts'ing Dynasty 1644-1912

The Kang-hsi paintings superficially looked at somewhat resemble those of the Sung period, but they lack the soul of the sublime paintings of that classic period. In the Chien-lung and the later periods there are many talented masters, but their ability seems to be of a technical nature and their works give the impression of decorative art.

KANG-HSI. 1662-1723 The famous artists are the four Wangs, especially Wang-shih-ku; Yün-nan-t'ien, as a flower painter; Sin-lo-shan-jön, for flowers and birds and Ch'a-shih-piao for landscapes.

YUNG-CHENG. 1723-1736. Kao-chi-p'ei, a famous finger painter.

CHIEN-LUNG. 1736-1796. Tung-pang-ta, landscapes; Pien-shou-min, geese and ducks.

KIA-CHING. 1796-1821. Min-chen, scenes of life, flowers and birds.

TAO-KUANG. 1821-1851 Wang-hsiao-meo, a famous copyist.

PRESENT PERIOD. 1851-1912.

General Note

In ascribing a painting to a certain artist, as the Collector has done in the following descriptive list, he would observe, as is well known, that Chinese experts consider the inscription upon a painting and even the use of the seal of the artist to whom the painting is ascribed as indicating not so much its authenticity as its fidelity to the style of the artist named.
The Paintings

Tang Dynasty 600-900

1 Wang-wei 王維 Spring landscape

In the foreground willow trees, a summer-house, a creek and a fisherman plying his trade; in the background a gigantic range of mountains. The picture is full of "Stimmung"; it is a good example of Wang-wei's art. Chinese writers say that Wang-wei's pictures were like poems and his poems like pictures.

The picture bears at the top lengthy inscriptions by Chao-tzu-ang, Tung-chi-chang, Wên-chêng-ming and Wang-shih-ku, which seem to be genuine. Of the originally vivid green colours of the mountains dark green shades only are left.

2 Wu-tao-tzu 吳道子 Mythological scene

It must be regarded as an impossible thing to find any genuine pictures by Wu-tao-tzu in China, except perhaps in the imperial collections. This copy seems to be a rather old one, at least early Ming; but it is in a hopeless condition. It consists only of hundreds of pieces, the colours are almost completely lost and no more of Wu-tao-tzu's art can be seen than that the figures were done exceedingly well. The inscriptions at the top are illegible.

3 Wu-tao-tzu 吳道子 A country house in the mountains

Attributed to Wu-tao-tzu, but a Tang or early Sung copy. A country-house leans against a steep mountain slope, pines, a lake, a girl in a boat, a waterfall and rocky peaks in the background. Judging from this specimen of his art one can understand why Wu-tao-tzu is known as the greatest of Chinese painters.
Five Dynasties 900-960

4 Han-hsi 韓熙
   A temple in a mountain valley
   Copy made in the Ts'ing Dynasty. Interesting as showing a transition from Tang to Sung style.

Sung Dynasty 960-1280

5 Kuo-hsi 郭熙
   Spring landscape in Szechuan
   Kang-hsi copy. The mountains, the water and the trees are very well executed, but the animals are without life and clumsy.

6 Kuo-hsi 郭熙
   Spring landscape
   Copy, probably late Ming. Charming scenery. The nervous brushwork points to the late Ming period.

7 Li-i'ang 李唐
   Cloudy mountain scenery
   Painted on paper with gold ground, partly touched up, especially in white. The contrast between the green of the gigantic mountain-ranges and the white of the clouds and the water-fall is very effective; indeed the picture might be called a symphony in gold, green and white.

8 Wang-hsien 王詵
   Lan-tchai-ho, a genius, walking over the waves
   In black and white on silk. Note the quiet lines in the graceful figure contrasting with the lively lines of the agitated sea.

9 Li-ying-ch'iu 李咸熙
   Winter landscape
   This painting shows in a remarkable way the disinterested love of nature which was typical of the Sung painters. It shows also their unsurpassed power of interpreting the soul of nature. A grandeur of conception dominates notwithstanding the delicacy of the details. The entire atmosphere of the painting is full of peace. This is among the best landscapes of the collection.

10 Tung-yüan 董源
    A rainy landscape
    Very delicate work, approaching the Yüan style.
11 Li-kung-lin 李公麟

Kang-hsi copy probably. A palace seen within the mist; sun sinking behind steep rocks; the god of longevity coming through the air on a heron. The faces and figures of the immortals are very well done also the palace and the whole background; but the rock in the middle-distance is without character, while the trees in the foreground have no life.

12 Su-tung-po 蘇東坡

A modern copy, the beauty of which lies in the various shades of black ink.

13 Mi-fei 米芾

Rainy landscape

14 Sung-hui-tsung 宋徽宗

White falcon tied to a rock

Genuine Sung-hui-tsungs are not readily found. This is a recent imitation done with the remarkable skill of the Chinese in forging old pictures.

15 Sung-hui-tsung 宋徽宗

An eagle looking from a rock in the sea

The inscription says that this is a copy by Pien-ching-chao, Yüan Dynasty, after an original by Sung-hui-tsung, but it must be a modern copy after Pien-ching-chao's copy. This and the preceding number give a good idea of Sung-hui-tsung's famous art of painting birds.

16 Ching-hao 趙浩

Autumn landscape

Although spoiled to a considerable extent it has not lost much of its original effect. The massive mountains are painted with an unusually powerful brush.

17 Yang-wu-ch'iu 楊無咎

Pine-tree, bamboo and larch blossoms in the moonshine

It is apparently only a small part of an originally much larger picture, but it has a charm difficult to describe and it is in the best style of the great Sung masters.

18 Chao-po-ku 趙伯駒

Summer in the high mountains

Excellent composition, fine colouring, especially the blue of the mountains. Full of the spirit of Sung art.
19 Chao-po-kü 趙伯駒 Emperor Min-wang and the goddess of the moon

The goddess surrounded by five girl companions drives in a two-wheeled carriage drawn by a phoenix through the clouds. The Emperor and the three other beings standing in the air look up to her. Simple composition and very refined colouring. This painting has the charm of the old legends.

20 Ma-yüan 馬遠 The eighteen Lohans

Possibly a Kang-hsi copy, if not a quite modern falsification. The whole is very well executed.

21 Ma-yüan 馬遠 Rain among the mountains

22 Chao-ta-nin 趙大年 Mountain scenery

An imposing cone-shaped mountain having in the foreground two very fine firs.

23 T'ung-kuan 童貫 A sage enjoying the beauty of a lake

A copy of the Ming period. This picture is poetry materialized.

24 Hsia-kuei 夏珪 The minister Sih-sü retiring into isolation

Broad style showing a countryhouse among lofty mountains.

25 Yen-tzu-ping 閻次平 The island of happiness

The mythical land where gold has no value and the people live in everlasting happiness.

26 Pei-loh-tien 白樂天 Ti-kwa-li, one of the eight Genii

27 Li-ti 李迪 The Si-hu or West Lake at Hangchow

Probably a Ts'ing copy.

28 Ku-chung-chiao 顧仲熙 Two herons

A Kang-hsi copy.

29 Wu-huai 吳懷 A dragon

A Ming copy. Wu-huai was a most famous dragon painter. Note the beautiful shades of black and white and the powerful design of the animal.
Yüan Dynasty 1280-1368

30 Chao-tzu-ang 趙子昂
   A hundred horses
   Probably a Ming copy. Very fine composition.

31 Chao-tzu-ang 趙子昂
   A horse whipped by his keeper
   Probably Ts'ing copy. Observe the ferocity of the head of the horse.
   The painting shows why Chao-tzu-ang is called the most famous horse
   painter after Han-kan of the Tang Dynasty.

32 Chao-tzu-ang 趙子昂
   An emperor hunting a deer
   Chien-lung copy.

33 Chao-tzu-ang 趙子昂
   A horse
   Probably Kang-hsi copy.

34 Chao-tzu-ang 趙子昂
   Summer landscape
   Kang-hsi copy.

35 Tang-tzu-hua 唐子華
   Spring in the mountains
   Typical of the style of the Yüan period. No longer the intimate feel-
   ing of the Sung masters, but a tendency to decoration and sentiment. The
   composition is still coherent. The lines across the picture were caused by
   its having fallen into water.

36 C'hi'en-hsüan 錢選
   Maku, the fairy, with a phoenix in the clouds
   Notice the rhythm of the lines in the drapery of Maku and the
   refined brush-work with which the bird is executed.

37 Ch'ien-hsüan 錢選
   Two pheasants on a stream in the mountains
   Probably a Ming copy.

38 Ch'ien-hsüan 錢選
   Lameh tree with blossoms, roses, daffodils and birds
   Probably a Ming copy.

39 Ch'ien-hsüan 錢選
   Poppies, butterflies and insects
   A Tao-kuang copy.
40 Ma-yih 馬逸

Wild geese and peonies

Poetical composition; the blossoms are of rare beauty and the geese, caught in typical positions, are full of life and truth to nature.

41 Huang-kung-wang 黃公望

Spring in the mountains

Probably Ts'ing copy. Characteristic of Yuan style.

42 Pien-ching-chao 邊景昭

Pheasants and other birds in bamboo

Ts'ing copy.

43 Pien-ching-chao 邊景昭

Titmice in a blossoming larch tree

44 Pien-ching-chao 邊景昭

Magnolias and peonies

Very impressive by its simplicity.

45 Pien-ching-chao 邊景昭

Pheasants and mynah by a cascade

Probably Ming copy.

46 Pien-ching-chao 邊景昭

A hundred quails

Ming copy. The original must have been still larger.

47 Mi-chia-chao 米佳詔

Rainy landscape

48 Chang-hsun 張遜

Spring in the mountains

Probably Kang-hsi copy.

49 Sung-juh-chih 宋汝志

Autumn landscape

Ming copy.

Ming Dynasty 1368-1644

50 T'ang-yin 唐寅

Romantic mountain scenery

This is an eminent work in the style of T'ang-yin. The dominating conical mountain in the left, the rifted rocks and the countryhouses in the foreground, the perspective of the valley in the background with the flight of ducks in the air create together a unique effect. All the line drawing seems to live. Only a proud and superior artist would have dared delineate a mountain like that on the left. If it were possible to get a genuine T'ang-yin in China, one would be inclined to regard this genuine; but it is a Ming copy.
51 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
The Lu mountains in Kiangsu  
Ming copy. Quite a different side of T'ang-yin's art. Painted with black ink on paper.

52 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
A pagoda and temple in the mountains  
Ts'ing copy after an early T'ang-yin.

53 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
Marsh-mallow  
Modern copy.

54 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
Autumn in the mountains  
Ts'ing copy. Characteristic of the style of T'ang-yin.

55 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
A garden in summer  
Ts'ing copy. Very refined work. Another instance of T'ang-yin's versatility.

56 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
A sage enjoying nature  
Modern copy. The bamboo is drawn well, but not the mountains.

57 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
Autumn in the high mountains  
Kang-hsi copy. Grand composition in black and white on paper.

58 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
A river in a mountainous country, autumn landscape  
Late Ming or Kang-hsi copy.

59 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
Wang-hsi-chih returning home after a long absence  
Modern imitation.

60 T'ang-yin 唐寅  
Lotus flower  
Ming copy.

61 Wên-chêng-ming 文徵明  
A harbour with many junks  
Probably an imitation.

62 Wên-chêng-ming 文徵明  
An autumn landscape  
Much injured but still showing Wên-chêng-ming's delicate brush.
63 Tung-ch'i-ch'ang 董其昌
   Rainy landscape
   Probably a copy. The misty atmosphere of a rainy day is wonderfully depicted.

64 Tung-ch'i-ch'ang 董其昌
   Landscape
   Probably a copy.

65 Lü-ki 呂記
   Nine herons
   Lü-ki was the most distinguished painter of birds during the Ming period.

66 Lü-ki 呂記
   Two pheasants above a rapid

67 Lü-ki 呂記
   Two herons under lotus leaves
   Modern copy.

68 Lü-ki 呂記
   Ducks falling into water
   Chien-lung copy.

69 Ts'ai-tze 蔡澤
   Winter landscape
   Very vigorous brush-work, and in style more Sung than Ming. There are very few specimens in which a Ming painter has achieved this grandeur of style.

70 Chang-ping-shan 張平山
   A sage in the rain
   The atmosphere of a rainy day could not be better represented; the work is of a very refined artist.

71 Chang-ch'un-chen-jen 長春真人
   Magpies in a tree

72 Chin-t'ao 金濤
   White peonies and a heron

73 Chü-shan 巨山
   Lotus flowers

74 Lu-pao-shan 陸包山
   Phoenix, storks, ducks and other birds

75 Lu-pao-shan 陸包山
   Camellias and other flowers

76 Lu-pao-shan 陸包山
   Mandarin ducks, rose-mallows, bindweeds and bamboo
   Chien-lung copy.
77 Ch'en-chang 陳璋  
Rose-mallows and butterflies

78 Wang-hsien 王謨  
The thunderstorm  
Finger painting. A picture of elementary power. Highest impressionistic skill.

79 Yu-tun (Prince) 有撥  
Magnolias and peonies
